During the last few days he developed sickness, chills and abdominal pain of sudden onset after heavy exercise I sent him for a general check at nearby outpatient clinic. 

A routine check-up involving ECG, chest X-ray, blood pressure measurement and determination of O2-saturation showed no significant abnormalities. The initial blood results showed slightly elevated leukocyte counts with 11.3 G/L, normal red blood cell counts (4.78 T/L) and normal platelets with 294 G/L (see Table ​Table1.1). The patient received transfusion of 1 L isotonic infusion solution and symptomatic therapy with metamizol and paracetamol.

 

Eight hours later, the mother called me since his general condition worsened rapidly.

 

Physical signs: the patient was not completely alert, was in pain, exhausted and febrile.

Vital signs: BT 40 °C, BP 100/60, HR 120

 

I alerted 118 Ambulance to be hospitalized at ED.

 

In Ambulance 

Vital signs: BT 40 °C, BP 100/60, HR 120, short breathing

ECG evaluation showed tachycardia with ST elevation in precordial lead mimicking an anteroseptal STEMI; ABG pH 6.95, pcO2 21, SB 5, BE -22, pO2 100;Fluid resuscitation therapy of crystalloids 500 mL/h was administered and O2 10 lit/pm.

 

 

ED blood test showed leukopenia (2.8 G/L), his platelet levels were low (108 G/L) and the serum creatinine was elevated (2.0 mg/dl). Hemostasis parameters were also altered (again depicted in Table ​Table1).1). A rapid test for S. pneumoniae-antigen was positive and although antimicrobial therapy was started immediately, the patient developed hemodynamic problems (systolic RR: 50 mmHg) and had to be transferred to an intensive care unit (ICU). In spite of catecholaminergic therapy, fluid resuscitation and intubation, the organ dysfunction of the patient deteriorated and he developed severe septic shock with metabolic acidosis (lactate 15 mmol/L), anuric renal failure, overt disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and fast spreading necrotic skin lesions, resembling purpura fulminans.

 

Upon admission, his hemodynamic and respiratory situation was stable. The metabolic acidosis, however, worsened: lactate levels increased to 18 mmol/L and signs of hepatic impairment were detectable with elevated transaminases and hypoglycemia. Moreover, creatine kinase (CK) levels were massively increased at 6678 U/L and myoglobin values ​​were at 11,500 ng/mL. The skin lesions progressed, and confluent lesions spread over the whole face, both hands and both feet. Hemostasis parameters showed thrombocytopenia (33 G/L), a PT of 31%, an aPTT of >180 s, fibrinogen values ​​of 72 mg/dl and massively elevated D-Dimer levels (72.19 μg/ml), resembling septic coagulopathy with purpura fulminans. According to local and international recommendations, coagulation therapy with a plasma-derived protein C concentrate (Ceprotin®, Baxalta), was initiated. An initial bolus dose of 100 U/kg body weight was given, followed by 10 U/kg/h, aiming for plasma protein C activity values ​​of 100 U/dL. Additional hemostatic therapy consisted of fibrinogen and platelet concentrates, antithrombin replacement (aiming for antithrombin levels of 100 U/dL), and low dose heparin infusion (250 U/kg BW/h). Moreover, extracorporeal renal replacement therapy had to be started because of acute renal failure.

 

Under this treatment the patient could be successfully stabilized. Although CK and myoglobin values ​​continued to increase during the next 3 days and the face and the limbs of the patient were impressively hypoperfused, there were no signs for a compartment syndrome, and no surgical intervention was necessary. After peaking at day 3 upon admission, CK values ​​decreased within the next weeks until returning into the normal range after 4 weeks. In parallel, also the hemostaseological parameters improved and the skin situation improved.

 

The renal situation, however, remained unchanged and until week 4 no sufficient renal function could be established. Therefore, the patient was changed from continuous hemofiltration to intermittent hemodialysis, which was well tolerated. Creatinine levels were constantly high, peaking with 7.95 mg/dl.

 

After 27 days, the patient could be transferred from the intensive care unit to our infectiological ward, where he stayed for another 26 days. Within this stay and under forced fluid substitution, his creatinine levels returned almost into normal range (1.27 mg/dl); also the urine output increased, so renal replacement therapy could be stopped after 4 weeks upon admission. In following, renal function returned to normal. The local skin situation improved constantly, necrotic areas were surgically removed and healed decently.

 

The patient could be finally transferred to a rehabilitation center, from which he was discharged and fully recovered.
Response:
Diagnosis:

Septic Shock

* Probability: Very High
* Emergency: Critical
* Rationale: The patient presented with septic shock signs: very high fever (40°C), hypotension (BP 100/60 initially, dropping to systolic 50 mmHg), tachycardia (HR 120), altered mental status, DIC, organ dysfunctions (renal failure, hepatic impairment), and confirmed S. pneumoniae infection. ABG results also supported this diagnosis with severe metabolic acidosis.

Suitable Treatments:
* Broad spectrum antibiotic (change to specfic antibiotic after colture analisis), fluid (crystalloids) replacement (to be established according to fluid tolerance and fluid responsiveness), norepinephrine to mantain mean arterial pressure above 65 mmHg (adding vasopressin in case of refractory shock),  ventilation support (mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 6 ml/kg is preferred)

Query:
39 yo M patient, ED setting
 

Patient came in ambulatory concerning about scrotum and penis pain and swelling with tiredness, discomfort, short of breath. He negates recent sexual intercourse and relevant clinical history.
 

Vital sign: BP 120/72 mmHg, BT 37.2°C, HR 90 bpm, Sp02 98%. Examination shows swelling, erythema of penis and scrotum. No heart, lung or neurological signs to be added.
 

Suspected diagnosis: bacterial infection
 

Therapy: blood test, urine test, blood culture, urine culture, antibiotic, monitoring.
 

At night patient condition get worse with dyspnoea. Doctor suggested admission to 118.
 

At ambulance was performed ECG that showed sinus tachycardia with a HR of 140 bpm.
Vital sign: RR 39/m, BP 120/75 mmHg, SpO2 97%, BT 37.9°C. Blood glucose was 240 mg/dl. Patient respond only to voice and pain. Arterial blood gas showed a marked compensated alkalosis with a lactate 3.9mmol/l. Blood test results showed a CRP 535 mg/l, urea 11 mmol/l and creatinine 200 µmol/l.
 

Suspected diagnosis: Fournier’s gangrene, sepsis.
The doctor diagnosis sepsis due to Fourier gangrene because the patient has HR>140 bpm, RR>25/m, lactate>2 mmol/l, patient responsiveness.
 

Therapy: Oxygen therapy, IV fluid resuscitation with crystalloid fluid, analgesic, blood cultures, antibiogram.
 

After 4 days Beta-haemolytic group A streptococcus was identified from the patient’s blood cultures. Antibiotic therapy was guided by the sensitivities.
The patient was followed up in the local plastic surgery department six weeks after leaving hospital for consideration of split skin grafting of unhealed areas.
Response:
Diagnosis:

Fournier’s Gangrene

* Probability: Very High
* Emergency: Critical/Emergency
* Rationale: Rapid progression of symptoms, significant swelling, and erythema of scrotum and penis, systemic signs of sepsis (elevated HR, RR, lactate levels, CRP, urea, and creatinine levels). High mortality if untreated promptly.

Suitable Treatments:
* Extensive, aggressive, and early surgical debridement is the primary mainstay of treatment

Query:
49 yo F patient, ED setting.
 

Her medical history: chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), coronary artery disease, arterial hypertension, and hyperlipidaemia.

 

Husband called us and I immediately called the 118 Ambulance that brought her to ED
 

She reported abdominal pain, right flank pain, and shortness of breath. Although the patient had previously been prescribed multiple medications, she stated that she had not taken them for 2 months due to she was feeling better and she forgot.
 

Vital sign: BT 38.3°C, BP 187/111 mmHg, SpO2 94%, HR 100 bpm. The patient’s abdomen was soft and tender with no guarding or rebound, but she did have costovertebral angle tenderness in the lower back, decreased bowel sign.
 

Suspected diagnosis: intra-abdominal infection.
 

IN ED 

 

Suggested therapy: blood test, urine test, blood culture, antiobiogram, abdomen CT, pelvic CT, urine culture
The patient’s lab results showed WBC 16,000/mm3, neutrophilia, blood glucose 127 mg/dL.
The CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed a 5x7 mm stone in the right ureter with moderate right hydronephrosis.
 

Suspected diagnosis: urinary tract infection, hydronephrosis, renal colic.
Doctor believed that the patient’s shortness of breath was due to pre-existing COPD.
Therapy: analgesic, ondansetron, antibiotic (ciprofloxacin), urologic visit.
The patient refused urologic admission and antibiotic. The next days she was admitted to ED and her condition get worse. She was still suffering from right flank pain that was intense. She also stated that she had not urinated very much (oliguria).
Vital signs: BP 151/86 mmHg, HR 93 bpm, RR 24/m, SpO2 97% BT 36°C.
 
The cultures showed gram negative rods. Antibiogram not ready.
Diagnosis: urinary tract infection UTI .
Therapy: analgesic, ondansetron, antibiotic (ciprofloxacin), urologic visit.
The patient refused admission.
Next day her condition got very bad. The patient was confused, dehydrated and had a fever. Blood test showed neutropenia, CT showed ureterolithiasis.
Diagnosis: sepsis, urosepsis.
Therapy: admission in urologic department
At urologic department she had a stent placed in the right ureter by the urologist, then she was admitted to the intensive care unit.
At ICU she developed pneumonia and suffered a massive stroke approximately a week after the third ED visit. Further complications developed, and the patient died several days after having the stroke.
Response:
Diagnosis:

Urosepsis

* Probability: High
* Emergency: High
* Rationale: Given the gram-negative rods in the urine culture, elevated white blood cell count, neutrophilia, oliguria, and symptoms of confusion and dehydration, progressing to sepsis is highly probable. Urosepsis emerged as a severe infection complication, confirmed by the nosocomial history of progressing symptoms.

Suitable Treatments:
* Broad spectrum antibiotic (change to specfic antibiotic after colture analisis), fluid (crystalloids) replacement (to be established according to fluid tolerance and fluid responsiveness), norepinephrine to mantain mean arterial pressure above 65 mmHg (adding vasopressin in case of refractory shock),  ventilation support (mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 6 ml/kg is preferred)

Query:
M patient, 2 yo, ED setting.
 

Patient hospitalized for asthenia, vomiting and severe hypokalemia (1.3 mEq) due to distal tubular acidosis. Not fever. No signs of infection. Discharge after 6 days.
After 3 days a new hospitalization for diarrhea and vomiting. Fever for 8 hours then BT return to 36°C. After 6 days fever at 39°C, patient not very alert, inconsolable crying.
Suspected diagnosis: bacterial infection
Initial Therapy: blood culture, urine culture, antibiotic (Ceftriaxone 250 mg x 2), antibiogram
After 1 day the culture turn positive for aerobic blood culture and after 9 hours for Gram negative;
Modified therapy: antibiotic (Gentamicin + Amoxicillin + clavulanic acid), Blood test.
After 4 days an initial response to therapy, with CRP dropping from 15.9 to 4.7, fever again at 39°C associated with leukopenia and thrombocytopenia, so doctor decided to call a consultancy with the Microbiology department, who suggested 2 blood cultures, fecal culture and therapy with Imipenem 120mg x 4 is started. Rapid improvement of clinical symptoms and fever.
Suggested therapy: antibiotic (imipenem), blood culture.
After 1 day the culture identified: A.junii/johnsonii in blood but A.junii/johnsonii was also isolated in faeces.
After 2 days:
Vital signs: BT 36.2°C, BP 120/80, HR 100 bpm, SpO2 99%. The CRP was CRP. Patient alert, oriented, collaborative, active.
Response:
Diagnosis:

Acinetobacter junii/johnsonii Bacteremia

* Probability: High
* Emergency: High
* Rationale:
 Patient presents with signs of hypotension, hypothermia, and altered mental status, which are classic symptoms of septic shock.
Suitable Treatments:
* antibiotic (Imipenem)

Query:
10-year-old girl ED setting

 

Clinical story: She suffered from a rollover trauma by a truck, resulting in an unstable pelvic fracture with a severe decollement of the right trunk. While undergoing treatment in our district, the patient received clindamycin and piperacillin/tazobactam (for Pseudomonas aeruginosa in tracheal secretion). 

 

The girl was then moved to ED for further surgical treatment. After admission, the patient underwent a right-sided hemipelvectomy and negative pressure wound therapy. Despite continued antibiotic therapy with piperacillin/tazobactam and clindamycin, the patient became septic. A wound biopsy and blood cultures revealed Gram-positive cocci, therefore therapy was changed to linezolid and meropenem. However, even with this broad antibiotic medication, no clinical improvement was observed. Further differentiation revealed a vancomycin-resistant, but teicoplanin-sensitive strain of E. faecium (Van-B VRE). Additionally, a linezolid resistance was detected. The minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) breakpoint for linezolid was >4 mg/l, both at our institutional site as well as at the reference laboratory (Robert Koch Institute, Wernigerode, Germany). The antimicrobial therapy was switched to daptomycin (350 mg/day; approximately 8 mg/kg), which was continued for 17 days. Due to this targeted therapy, infection parameters normalized and her clinical status improved rapidly. After secondary wound closure, she was transferred to a rehabilitation center.
Response:
Diagnosis:

Septicemia

* Probability: Very High
* Emergency: Critical
* Rationale: The patient is experiencing a systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) with evidence of bacterial infection as indicated by positive blood cultures, indicating sepsis. Septicemia was further complicated by the identification of vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE), which required specific antibiotics for resolution.

Suitable Treatments:
* antibiotic daptomycin

Query:
A 50-year-old woman ED setting
 
Clinica history: Case known for mitral valve prolapse was admitted to hospital for elective surgery. The patients additional significant medical history included a gastric ulcer, hypertension, acute myocardial infarction, and cardiac asthma. The surgery lasted for 5 hours; cefuroxim plus tobramycin were administered as antibiotic prophylaxis prior to surgery, according to the local protocols. Postoperatively the patient had to be resuscitated; an intra-aortic balloon pump was required to wean the patient off of the heart-lung machine. 
After the patient was successfully resuscitated, she was transferred to the intensive care unit, where she remained intubated and ventilated for 29 hours. Eight days after the operation Enterococcus faecalis, Escherichia coli, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa were isolated from the femoral wound, but antimicrobial treatment was not applied. The patient was afebrile. Her white cell count was 8.4 x 109/liter, C reactive protein level was at 78mg/liter and the sedimentation rate was 84mm/hr. Two days later, the patient had a leukocyte count of 14.75 x 109 /l, a CRP of 38.42 mg/l, and a WE of 60 mm/h were measured. 
 
The patient was moved to ED for the second time. At that time the femoral wound required binding. Six months later, no wound infection was detected at the control examination. This is the first report of isolation of vanA carrying E. faecalis in Apulia, and this is the first demonstration of vanA carrying E. faecalis in Apulia confirmed by sequence analysis. Surprisingly, this patient never received vancomycin. It is also possible that the vancomycin resistance emerged in the medical staff members and was nosocomially transmitted to the patient. However, the environmental, staff and patient screening were negative for VRE. Although, the patient had never received vancomycin therapy, she may have been more susceptible to environmental pathogen bacteria due to multiple severe concomitant diseases.
Response:
Diagnosis:

surgical infection

* Probability: High
* Emergency: High. Untreated infections, particularly in an immunocompromised patient, can rapidly lead to sepsis or other serious complications.
* Rationale: The patient has a history of being in an ICU with prolonged intubation and an invasive procedure (surgery). She has developed a wound infection from multiple pathogens (Enterococcus faecalis, Escherichia coli, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa).

Suitable Treatments:
* antibiotics

Query:
A 49 year old male obese and smoker ED setting

 

He was admitted to ED with complaints of chest pain, shortness of breath, and chills for the past two weeks. He describes the pain as sharp and located on the left side of his chest. 

Past medical history is non-contributory, except for current IV drug use. 

Vital signs: BT 36.5 ° C, BP 141/63, HR 87, RR 18 with an oxygen saturation of 91-93% on room air. 

Physical exam: a regular rate & rhythm with no murmur or regurgitation was noted and lungs showed fine bilateral crackles. 

 

His white blood cell count was increased at 22.1 TH/cm2 and troponin I was also elevated at 0.19 ng/ml. Blood cultures were collected and the patient was started on ceftaroline and piperacillin tazobactam for presumed infectious endocarditis. He was transferred to the medical intensive care unit (ICU) and intubated due to respiratory distress. An echocardiogram revealed a large mobile vegetation on the aortic valve with severe insufficiency and a vegetation & thickening of the mitral valve with severe regurgitation.

 

Blood cultures were positive within 24 hours of collection and gram positive cocci arranged in pairs and chains were noted (Image 1). Enterococcus spp., vancomycin resistance not detected was reported by polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Small, gray, non-hemolytic colonies grew after 2 days of incubation (Image 2). MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry identified the isolate as Enterococcus faecalis.

 

Ampicillin or vancomycin are acceptable treatment options for Enterococcal infections if found to be susceptible by antibiotic testing. It is important to note, Enterococcus spp. are intrinsically resistant to cephalosporins, aminoglycosides, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and clindamycin. For serious infections, including infective endocarditis, treating with a cell wall active agent such as ampicillin and an aminoglycoside (gentamicin or streptomycin) is recommended to create a synergistic bactericidal effect. The emergence of E. faecium acquired vancomycin resistance (VanA/VanB) is increasing and more board spectrum agents such as daptomycin and linezolid are necessary to effectively treat these infections. 

 

In this, upon identification of E. faecalis from multiple blood cultures, his antibiotics were switched to IV ampicillin and gentamicin. He underwent valve replacement surgery and the aortic and mitral valves grew E.faecalis and showed numerous bacterial cocci on histology. He completed a six-week course of ampicillin and gentamicin and was discharged home in good condition.
Response:
Diagnosis:

Infective Endocarditis

* Probability: Very High
* Emergency: Critical
* Rationale: The presence of a large, mobile vegetation on the aortic valve with severe insufficiency and similar findings on the mitral valve is highly indicative of IE. The patient’s IV drug use is a significant risk factor for this condition. Elevated white blood cell count and positive blood cultures for gram-positive cocci arranged in chains, specifically Enterococcus faecalis, strongly support this diagnosis. The detection of vegetation with echocardiography confirms the diagnosis.

Suitable Treatments:
* antibiotics

Query:
A 64-year-old woman obese, non smoker ED settings 

 

She was moved to ED with fever and weakness over the last few days. The patient was feeling agitated during the physical examination. She also complained of left back pain. Her medical history included poorly controlled type II diabetes mellitus and chronic renal failure.

 

She was drowsy. Her vital signs were as follows: body temperature, 37.5 °C; pulse rate, 102 beats/min; respiratory rate, 28 breaths/min; blood pressure, 122/54 mmHg (noradrenaline 0.5 microg/kg per min); and pulse oxygen saturation, 98% with high flow oxygen therapy. Diminished breath sounds in the right lower lung were heard on auscultation. There was no audible cardiac murmur. Her abdomen was soft but she failed to cooperate with the abdominal tenderness examination, along with mild pitting edema of both lower limbs. The patient was diagnosed with emphysematous pyelonephritis and septic shock, possibly caused by a gas-producing uropathogenic infection.

Laboratory results demonstrated that her white cell count was 27,700 cells per cubic millimeter (the normal range: 3,500 to 9,500). The C-reactive protein level was 32.873 mg per deciliter, the blood urea nitrogen level was 20.70 mmol per liter, and the creatinine level was 312.7 μmol per liter. Urinalysis showed an elevated leukocyte count and bacteriuria. A CT scan in horizontal plane sectioning showed that the left kidney was significantly enlarged with thickened perirenal fascia, which was related to the presence of gas in the renal parenchyma and the kidney pelvis. She was transferred to the intensive care unit and treated with meropenem and broad-spectrum empirical antibiotics.

 

Unfortunately, the patient developed acute renal failure and was treated with continuous renal replacement therapy. After active treatment, the clinical effect was remarkable. Her clinical symptoms and serum inflammatory indicators  improved gradually, and she stopped using norepinephrine (day 3). Her renal function (day 3) also recovered , and she was successfully weaned with continuous renal replacement therapy. On the third day, both blood and urine cultures reported extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL)-producing E. coli. The patients condition continued to improve, and she no longer needed to be treated in the ED on the 6th day. The patients abdominal CT scan (day 12) revealed that the gas collection in the pelvis and calyces had disappeared. Finally, the patient was discharged.
Response:
Diagnosis:

Probability ~70%
* Emergency: High
* Rationale: The CT scan clearly showed gas in the renal parenchyma, indicating emphysematous pyelonephritis, which is a severe form of urinary tract infection often seen in diabetics.

Suitable Treatments:
* resuscitation, correction of any electrolyte and glucose problems, and administration of antibiotics targeting Gram-negative bacteria

Query:
A 71-year-old male obese smoker

 

History of benign prostatic hyperplasia, nephrolithiasis, and coronary artery disease status/post coronary artery bypass graft. Right flank pain, followed by fever, chills, sickness, abdominal pain, and nausea. He took acetaminophen for pain. He denied dysuria, gross hematuria, prior urethral stricture, diarrhea, poor dentition, or alcohol use. He flosses daily and follows with his dentist regularly, with teeth cleaning 1 month prior to presentation. He denied recent sexual activity. Physical exam was positive for fever (38.0 degree Celsius), tachycardia, and diaphoresis. Capillary refill was normal. 

 

He was admitted to ED. Initial laboratory results showed mild leukocytosis, normocytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, acute kidney injury with creatinine 2.2, and estimated glomerular filtration rate 29. Urine showed microscopic hematuria and small leukocytes. Computed tomography abdomen/pelvis demonstrated moderate right hydronephrosis  and a 10 mm right ureteral stone and multiple nonobstructing left renal calculi. 

The patient was treated with aggressive intravenous (IV) fluid hydration and IV Ceftriaxone. Urology was consulted, and a right ureteral stent was placed. Due to unresolving sepsis, antibiotics were broadened to IV Vancomycin and Piperacillin/Tazobactam. Blood and urine cultures resulted positive for S. sanguinis. Infectious disease was consulted for treatment of his streptococcus bacteremia. Additional workup was negative for infectious endocarditis including a transesophageal echocardiogram. Antibiotics were de-escalated to IV ceftriaxone 2 g every 24 hours. The patient completed a 2-week course of IV ceftriaxone. Follow-up blood cultures remained negative, and his renal function normalized. The right stent was later exchanged with lithotripsy of the right renal calculus.

 

The iliopsoas abscess was resolved by percutaneous drainage and medical treatment with ampicillin/sulbactam. There are few documented cases of iliopsoas abscess caused by urinary tract infections, which were primarily posturologic interventions and in association with ureteral stones.

Patient was also found to have a right renal calculus and hydronephrosis which was likely the source of the S. sanguinis urinary sepsis. The medical literature has documented penicillin susceptibility for Streptococcus sanguinis to be 60%. Ceftriaxone and vancomycin susceptibility was shown to be 92% and 100%, respectively. The guidelines for infective endocarditis recommend penicillin G and ceftriaxone as 1st-line therapy for viridans streptoccus endocarditis.
Response:
Diagnosis:

Pyelonephritis with Urosepsis

* Probability: High
* Emergency: High
* Rationale: The patients symptoms (fever, chills, flank pain), laboratory findings (leukocytosis, hematuria), imaging results (hydronephrosis, ureteral stone), and positive blood/urine cultures (S. sanguinis) are consistent with a severe urinary tract infection progressing to sepsis.

Suitable Treatments:
* Broad spectrum antibiotic (change to specfic antibiotic after colture analisis), fluid (crystalloids) replacement (to be established according to fluid tolerance and fluid responsiveness), norepinephrine to mantain mean arterial pressure above 65 mmHg (adding vasopressin in case of refractory shock),  ventilation support (mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 6 ml/kg is preferred)

Query:
A 78-year-old woman overweight non smoker (Dentistry and Oral-Maxillo Surgery Department)

 

It was requested re-fabrication of the upper and lower partial dentures and underwent an initial examination at our general dental department on February 20 2024. 

 

The patient had a medical history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and renal calculi and was taking trichlormethiazide , warfarin potassium, and fluvastatin sodium tablets; therefore, her blood pressure, lipid levels, and renal calculi were within normal ranges.

 

The lower partial dentures were re-fabricated and re-fabrication of the upper partial dentures was planned once the adjustment of the lower partial dentures was complete.

 

On April 16 the patient was experiencing intense instability (tooth mobility level 3) in the upper left molar region, so the procedure was re-scheduled to take place after extraction of the tooth . At that point, no marked reddening or swelling of the upper left molar region was observed, and tooth extraction was scheduled to be performed at a later date. Dental X-rays of the upper left molar region indicated marked alveolar bone resorption.

 

Subsequently, the patient experienced spontaneous pain and swelling in the upper left molar region and was examined at general dental department on April 24. Pus discharge from the periodontal pocket was observed, and the area was cleaned and sterilized with normal saline solution and iodoglycol paste. Loxoprofen sodium was prescribed as an analgesic.

 

A few days later, the swelling spread to the left buccal region and spontaneous pain became more intense, leading to more difficulty while eating for 2–3 days. On April 28, the primary care physician instructed the patient to back to hospital. That day, upon examination  the Glasgow Coma Scale score was 11. The patient was immediately referred to the dental anesthesiology department, and the physical findings included facial pallor, cold hands and fingers, and shivering. Palpation indicated a weak radial artery pulse, and the vital signs were as follows: axillary temperature, 41°C; systolic blood pressure, 80–90 mmHg; diastolic blood pressure, 40–50 mmHg; pulse rate, 130–160 bpm; and SpO2, 75%–85%.

 

Based on the physical findings and vital signs, dehydration and septic shock were suspected. 

 

Oxygen administration at 10 L/min was immediately initiated using a face mask. A venous line was secured to the cubital fossa after the blood was drawn for a rapid blood examination, and drip infusion of acetate linger solution (500 mL) and normal saline solution (100 mL) with ampicillin sodium (2 g) was initiated. Blood examination results referred to possible malnutrition based on albumin (2.3 g/dL) and sodium (127 mEq/L) levels, and severe infection was suspected based on white blood cell count (29,830/µL) and C- reactive protein levels (22.86 mg/dL). After the venous infusion of antibacterial drugs, there were signs of improvement, and a consciousness level of 14 was observed on the Glasgow Coma Scale, with an axillary temperature of 38.5°C, systolic blood pressure of 120–130 mmHg, diastolic blood pressure of 80–90 mmHg, pulse rate of 120–140 bpm, and SpO2 of 100% when oxygen was administered at 10 L/min using a face mask.

 

Subsequently, the patient was transferred to ED and blood examinations were performed; the results showed high levels of D-dimer (23.98 µg/mL) and fibrin degradation products (38.6 µg/mL) were found; thus, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) was strongly suspected. Therefore, the patient underwent systemic management in intensive care unit. However, her condition worsened at around midday on the following day, and her death was confirmed at 9:22 p.m. on April 29.

 

On the following day, the patients family requested an explanation regarding the treatment at our hospital. The general dentistry department manager, dental anesthesiologist, and relevant office staff explained the patients course and state to her until the emergency transfer and the treatment that she was given, which her family understood. Furthermore, the family mentioned that the patient may have had lung cancer based on the findings of magnetic resonance imaging and computed tomography performed at the general hospital, which indicated pleural effusion, pulmonary infiltration, and pulmonary shadows.
Response:
Diagnosis:

Sepsis/Septic Shock

* Probability: Very High
* Emergency: Immediate
* Rationale: The patients vitals, specifically elevated temperature (41°C), hypotension (80-90/40-50 mmHg), tachycardia (130-160 bpm), and low SpO2 (75%-85%), along with physical signs of dehydration, indicate sepsis. The rapid clinical deterioration, marked increase in white blood cell count (29,830/µL), and elevated C-reactive protein (22.86 mg/dL) further support the diagnosis.

Suitable Treatments:
* Broad spectrum antibiotic (change to specfic antibiotic after colture analisis), fluid (crystalloids) replacement (to be established according to fluid tolerance and fluid responsiveness), norepinephrine to mantain mean arterial pressure above 65 mmHg (adding vasopressin in case of refractory shock),  ventilation support (mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 6 ml/kg is preferred)

Query:
An 82-year-old Asian woman ex smoker 
 
I was called home by her son. 
No medical history or underlying disease. 
 
The whole condition started 24 hours after they went to eat seafood. Symptoms in the right upper arm developed 1 day after the patient shelled a large number of shrimp; therefore, the infection route was assumed to be through wounds sustained during shrimp shelling.
 
Physical examination: She developed redness, swelling, nausea, and pain, which extended from the right fingers to the upper arm. Other symptoms, diarrhea, fever 38.9°C, difficulty seeing, dry mouth, passing little to no urine, and difficulty keeping fluids down, some bloody urine.
 
Vital signs: BP 100/55, HR 115, SpO2 96%
 
Suspected diagnosis: sepsis due to shelling seafood. 
 
Called 118 Ambulance with red code to go to ED
 
Rehydration with intravenous fluids and electrolytes for severe dehydration; was administered large spectrum antibiotics for severe food poisoning from bacteria, such as E. coli, Salmonella, or Listeria. and she was monitored for complications such as kidney or nerve damage. O2 was given 5lit/pm.
 
Vital signs: BP 98/55, HR 115, SpO2 96% (room air); ECG showed an anterolateral ST elevation, with well-formed QS-waves in V1-V3, diagnosis of subacute anterolateral STEMI.
She did have a mild ketoacidosis as well.
 
ED settings
 
Vital and physical signs: facial pallor, quite confused, redness, mild swelling, and pain in the right arm. She was in circulatory shock with a blood pressure of 60/48 mmHg, pulse rate, 91 beats per minute (bpm; regular); respiratory rate, 22 breaths/minute; SpO2, 97% (room air); body temperature, 37.7 °C.
 
Blood tests showed high levels of inflammation, and computed tomography of the upper arm revealed adipose tissue turbidity. It was suspected septic shock, with the infection originating in the upper arm.
 
To stabilize blood pressure, it was administered 1000 mL of lactated Ringers solution, an initial dose of meropenem 1.0 g after blood culture specimens were collected, and noradrenaline at 0.2 µg/kg/minute. Then, under local anesthesia, a 5-cm incision was made distally from the medial right upper arm and proximally from the medial right cubital fossa. The color tones of the subcutaneous fat and fascia were normal, and it was suspected cellulitis rather than necrotizing fasciitis. For the septic shock, it was continued to administer meropenem (3.0 g/day) for 12 days, with linezolid (1.2 g/day) for 5 days and immunoglobulin (5 g/day) for 3 days via intravenous injection. On day 2 of hospitalization, a blood culture detected Gram-negative bacilli, and linezolid was discontinued. On day 5 of hospitalization, V. vulnificus was identified by blood culture, and we added minocycline (100 mg) twice daily for 8 days, to which V. vulnificus was susceptible (Fig. 3b). Subsequently, the inflammatory findings rapidly improved; the patients C-reactive protein levels dropped from 9.3 to 1.1 mg/dL in 9 days. Although there was no history of seafood intake or contact with seawater, we learned that the swelling developed in her right hand 1 day after she had shelled a large number of raw shrimp for cooking, and the swelling spread to the trunk. Therefore, we believed that the route of V. vulnificus infection was through minor skin wounds inflicted by shrimp shells.
 
The disease course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged on day 25 of hospitalization.  The medical staff suspected liver disease and measured serum anti-mitochondrial M2 antibody levels, leading to the diagnosis of primary biliary cholangitis.
Response:
Diagnosis:

Vibrio vulnificus Septicemia with Secondary Cellulitis

* Probability: High
* Emergency: Critical
* Rationale: The onset of symptoms following shelling raw shrimp and the identification of *Vibrio vulnificus* in the blood culture are strong indicators. The rapid progression of symptoms, including redness, swelling, and septic shock, aligns with a serious soft tissue infection.

Suitable Treatments:
* Broad spectrum antibiotic (change to specfic antibiotic after colture analisis), fluid (crystalloids) replacement (to be established according to fluid tolerance and fluid responsiveness), norepinephrine to mantain mean arterial pressure above 65 mmHg (adding vasopressin in case of refractory shock),  ventilation support (mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 6 ml/kg is preferred)

Query:
patient was a 78-year-old Male in ED setting from territorial medical guard and 118 Ambulance

 

The son called me for home visit 

 

The patient complained of 24 hours duration of pain, swelling and redness of his left dorsalis pedis. He had fever and was confused. 

 

His previous history included gastroenteritis after having shrimps with his wife. He also had gastroenteritis he was prescribed antibiotics but after initiating medication the patient became unconscious. 

 

His past medical history included bipolar disorder, multiple myeloma, osteoporosis, earlier pituitary tumor and development of frontotemporal dementia.

 

On physical examination, his Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) was 3, BP 79/38mmHg, HR 115 beats/minute, SpO2 60%, RR 40 breaths/minute, BT 39 °C. 

 

In the ambulance he was treated with metaoxedrine, epinephrine, clemastine, oxygen and isotonic sodium chloride. Before entering ED he was awake and had GCS 9, BP 87/43mmHg, HR 110 beats/minute, SpO2 90%, RR 35 breaths/minute. 

 

He was treated with methylprednisolone, ciprofloxacin and meropenem. ABG pH 7.11, lactate 4.8mmol/L, PaO2 11.9, PaCO2 34, bicarbonate 17mmol/L and hemoglobin 4.2mmol/L. 

 

He went hypotensive again and developed a cardiac arrest. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation was performed, epinephrine was administered and return of spontaneous circulation was observed after 2 minutes. Sedation and intubation was performed and he was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU). A nurse observed diffuse redness on his left foot, high temperature, petechiae and pain. His right lower leg had petechiae too and minor edema. C-reactive protein (CRP) was 175mg/L, white blood cells 1.0×109/L, platelets 56×109/L and the treatment with meropenem and ciprofloxacin continued combined with metronidazole and fluconazole.

 

A cardiac echo revealed ejection fraction >55%, a minor mitral valve deficiency and a well-preserved left ventricle. Treatment with inotropic agents was initiated, using norepinephrine because of volume-resistant hypotension and decreased urine output.

 

The next day an orthopedic surgeon assessed  suspicious of necrotizing fasciitis. On his left foot there was redness, bullae, cyanotic toes and there was no palpable pulse in the dorsalis pedis artery. Microscopic examination found Gram-negative bacteria after Gram-stained smears in all samples from the patient. The treatment with meropenem and metronidazole continued. His CRP was 284mg/L.

 

The microbiology identified Vibrio metschnikovii in all his blood samples using matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry. It was suggested treatment with meropenem and piperacillin/tazobactam since the antibiotic susceptibility tests found the bacillus to be sensitive to these antibiotics. His CRP was 318mg/L. He went to surgery and wound necrosis was found on top of vital tissue. 

 

Treatment with ciprofloxacin was canceled and the next step was either treatment with vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) system or in worst case amputation. His CRP was 262mg/L.

 

The following days his CRP decreased, this urine output increased and at that time the only antibiotic he was taking was piperacillin / tazobactam. The wound healing improved day by day, but he remained sleepy and needed mechanical ventilation. A tracheostomy was established 13 days after admission and he slowly improved during the following days of weaning from the ventilator. During this period he underwent surgical revision twice.

 

Piperacillin/tazobactam was discontinued and the tracheostomy was replaced with an uncuffed tube as he now could manage spontaneous respiration. He was transferred from ICU to internal medicine department 20 days after admission to hospital. A VAC system was established on his left foot and split-skin transplantation was performed 5 weeks after admission to hospital. He was still in hospital 3 months after admission.
Response:
Diagnosis:

Septic Shock

* Probability: High
* Emergency: Emergency
* Rationale: The patient presented with a high fever, hypotension, high lactate levels, and confusion, hallmark features of septic shock. Blood cultures confirmed the presence of Vibrio metschnikovii, a known pathogen that can cause severe sepsis.

Suitable Treatments:
* Broad spectrum antibiotic (change to specfic antibiotic after colture analisis), fluid (crystalloids) replacement (to be established according to fluid tolerance and fluid responsiveness), norepinephrine to mantain mean arterial pressure above 65 mmHg (adding vasopressin in case of refractory shock),  ventilation support (mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 6 ml/kg is preferred)

Query:
53 yo M, smoker, overweight

This patient has a past medical history of ischemic cerebral ischemia due to a foramen ovale in 1997, closure of that foramen in 2010. He went to the territorial medical guard for left flank abdominal pain and fever, the doctor prescribed anti-inflammatory drug (ibuprofen) and paracetamol. After 4 days he went to ED. 

Vital signs: BT 38.6 °C, HR 100 bpm, BP 120/80 mmHg, SpO2 98%. The left flank was sensitive at palpation without rebounds pain. Doctor prescribed blood test and arterial gas analysis that showed acute inflammation, with WBC 17.2× 109/L (leucocytosis) and a CRP value at 337 mg/l. Hemoglobin, hemostasis parameters, creatinine, liver and pancreatic tests were within the normal ranges. Arterial blood pH and lactate values were also normal. He also performed CT that showed a necrosis of the spleen with air, associated with a thin ipsilateral pleural effusion.

Suspected diagnosis: spleen necrosis, spleen abscess, sepsis.

Initial therapy:  fluid challenge (3 l of crystalloids), antibiotic (ceftriaxone and metronidazole), transfer to intensive care unit for monitoring, blood cultures

The blood cultures were positive for Clostridium perfringens and Streptococcus gallolyticus. Antibiotics were switched to amoxicilline-clavulanate and clindamycin, the latter for its potential effect on clostridial toxin production through interference with ribosomal protein synthesis. A transthoracic cardiac ultrasonography was performed and showed a normal cardiac function without valvular dysfunction nor endocarditis. After 12 h, was performed a splenectomy by midline incision. Samples of peri splenic purulent liquid were harvested. The spleen was exposed, allowing visualizing a voluminous perforated abscess. The spleen was extracted. After local washing, a drain was left in place, the abdominal wall was closed using absorbable stiches and a prophylactic cutaneous negative therapy device was applied. Perioperative bacteriological samples were positive for Clostridium perfringens, Streptococcus gallolyticus and Clostridium baratii. The patient stayed 24 h in perioperative care unit before returning to the ward. The drain was removed after 6 days and antibiotics were continued for 14 days. Endocarditis was definitively excluded using transoesophageal ultrasonography. To rule out associated pathology of the gastro-intestinal tract, a colonoscopy was performed and was normal. The patient was vaccinated against Streptococcus pneumonia, Neisseria meningitidis and Influenza, before being discharged 17 days after admission. Microscopic pathologic examination showed also a ruptured aneurysm of a branch of the splenic artery, surrounded by a splenic infarction.
Response:
Diagnosis:

spleen rupture, spleen abscess, spleen infraction, sepsis

* Probability: Very high
* Emergency: High
* Rationale: Symptoms of fever, left flank pain, elevated WBC count, high CRP, presence of necrosis and gas on CT, and positive blood cultures indicating infection all strongly suggest a splenic abscess.

Suitable Treatments:
* antibiotic, support therapy

Query:
64 yo female, ED setting, autonomous

Medical history of diabetes, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and hyperlipidemia 

She came in hospital because of fever and pain on the left hip joint. She underwent cemented THA on the left hip joint with transtrochanteric approach at 63 years old the symptoms appeared suddenly 9 months after the operation. 

On admission vital sign: BT 38.4°C, BP 130/80 mmHg, HR 92 bpm, SpO2 99%. 

Patient alert, collaborative, oriented. The left thigh was swollen and tender. Blood examination showed her WBC × 109/L   and CRP was 24.7 mg/dL. Was performed RX that was normal. However, T1 weighted magnetic resonance imaging (RMN) showed high-intensity area around her left hip joint and gluteus. We tried arthrocentesis, but very poor amount of synovial fluid appeared. Hence, we performed synovial fluid culture, but cell count was not available. She was started intravenous ceftriaxone 1 g/day from the day of admission after collecting of samples of blood culture, but both blood and synovial fluid culture turned out to be negative. 

First diagnosis: prothesis infection, sepsis

First therapy: arthrocentesis, blood culture, site culture, antibiotic (ceftriaxone 1 g/day), antiobiogram 

To identify the causative bacterium, we remove the wire in her greater trochanter and debride granulation and synovia on the 26th day. From multiple pieces of the trochanteric wires, granulation, and synovia, Y. enterocolica was detected, and it was susceptible to ceftriaxone. We suggested revision arthroplasty to her, but she never agreed because the symptom subsided, so we continued treatment by antibiotics. Her symptoms subsided, and CRP kept negative, so we changed the antibiotics to oral ciprofloxacin which was susceptible to the causative bacterium on the 61st day and we continued the treatment to the 74th day. She discharged on the 76th day. No recurrence has been seen in 24 months after the discharge.
Response:
Diagnosis:

Prosthetic Joint Infection

* Probability: High
* Emergency: High
* Rationale: PJI requires timely intervention to prevent further complications such as sepsis.

Suitable Treatments:
* antibiotic due to culture and antibiogramm(ceftriaxone 1 g/day then switch to oral ciprofloxacin 1g for 14 days), monitoring (blood test) arthroplasty revision

Query:
86 yo, F patient, ED setting, autonomous, hypothyroidism, pacemaker carrier, COPD, asthma.

She went in hospital because of accidental falling. She hadn’t memory loss, vomiting, loss of consciousness or neurological sign. 

Vital sign: HR 84 bpm, BP 121/68 mmHg, BT 36.2°C, SpO2 99%. She present sign of trauma on her left head and left part of chest. The signs are erythema and pain and skin abrasion of
Response:
Diagnosis:

Soft Tissue Trauma/Contusion

* Probability: High
* Emergency: Moderate
* Rationale: The patient presents erythema, pain, and skin abrasion following a fall. No signs of more severe internal injuries or neurological symptoms reported.

Suitable Treatments:
* TC of head, chest X-ray, analgesic, rest, monitoring if medication are sufficient, bone densitometry, medication

Query:
F patient, 73 yo, ED setting, autonomous. She has hypercholesterolemia in therapy with statin.

Patient came for abdominal pain, the pain is colic, she got 2 diarrhoea episode and 1 of vomit.

Vital signs: BP 100/70 mmHg, HR 80 bpm, BT 36,6 °C, SpO2 99%. Patient has mild pain at palpation of right mid abdomen. She is anxious. No neurological sign.
Response:
Diagnosis:



* Probability: High
* Emergency: Moderate
* Rationale: The colicky nature of the abdominal pain, episodes of diarrhea, and vomiting strongly suggest a gastrointestinal infection or inflammation.

Suitable Treatments:
* hydration, analgesic, anxiolytic (diazepam)

Query:
48 yo, F patient, autonomous, overweight, territorial ambulatory setting, smoker.

She came in hospital for needle lesion that after 7 days became swollen and red. Patient has drug allergy at penicillin antibiotic. She doesn’t have relevant medical condition.

Vital sign: HR 80 bmp, BP 131/71mmHg, SpO2 98%, BT 36.2 °C. Patient alert, collaborative, oriented. The fingertip has erythema, is swollen and painful, no pus.
Response:
Diagnosis:

Cellulitis

* Probability: High
* Emergency: Moderate
* Rationale: Cellulitis is a bacterial skin infection characterized by redness, swelling, and pain. The absence of pus suggests a non-abscess, diffuse inflammation, likely progressing from a needle lesion. The localized erythema, swelling, and pain are consistent with this diagnosis.

Suitable Treatments:
* antibiotic (gentamicin for 10 days), monitoring if there no lesion regression or disease progression change antibiotic

Query:
a 64-year-old Japanese female overweight and smoker (Dental ED)

History of Cogan's syndrome was brought by 118 ambulance to ED due to her high

fever, chills, and dizziness. She was emergently hospitalized because of hypoxemia

and cardiac insufficiency.

The initial examination showed hypoxemia (SpO2 81%), tachycardia (pulse rate

130/min), and high fever (39.4°C). Her level of consciousness was I-1 (JCS) and her

blood pressure was 97/56 mmHg. Echocardiography showed pulmonary

hypertension (RVSP 110). A CT scan showed bilateral pulmonary congestion and

obvious pulmonary artery dilatation. A blood test showed a low white blood cell count

(WBC 3900, Neutrophils 80.1%), anemia of chronic disease (RBC 321 × 104/μL, Hb

9.7 g/dL), thrombopenia (PLT 14.7 × 104/μL), and increased inflammatory response

(CRP 10.07 mg/dL).

The patient had been diagnosed with Cogan's syndrome in 2008, which had shown

(1) vestibular disorder, (2) auditory disorder, (3) ocular inflammation, (4) aortitis, and

(5) hypertrophic pachymeningitis/meningitis since 2006. She also had autoimmune

hemolytic anemia (AIHA). Since symptoms (1–3) had been stable since the

diagnosis, she underwent a cochlear implantation and a cataract operation. She had

been taking 14 mg prednisolone for the prior seven years as the primary treatment

for Cogan's syndrome and was consequently in immunocompromised status. She

had been taking an alendronate (bisphosphonate) for 2 years and 9 months.

At this time, sepsis was suspected and empirical antibiotic treatment was started

with i.v. meropenem (1 g every 8 h). Although the infectious focus had not been

identified, the physician in charge suspected odontogenic infection as one of the

candidate infectious foci, because she had been complaining of a toothache in the

left mandible. Cellulitis of unknown cause in the left ankle had been observed 2 days

before here hospitalization and she was also considered as another candidate for

the infectious focus.

To investigate the possibility of odontogenic infection, the patient was referred to our

department of oral and maxillofacial surgery 5 days after her hospitalization. Gram-

positive cocci had been detected in her venous blood culture at the initial

hospitalization. However, the species of the bacteria had not yet been identified. Just

 

before the hospitalization, the pain in her left lower molar had been so severe that

she had sometimes been unable to sleep. However, at her first presentation of her in

ED, the only thing she described was discomfortness of the left lower molar, and no

acute symptoms were observed.

As clinical findings, no inflammatory reactions such as swelling of the gingiva,

discharge of pus, severe dental caries, or periodontitis were apparent in the oral

cavity including the region about which the patient complained. The oral hygiene

condition was quite well. Only slight percussion pain was observed in the left

mandibular molars. The maximum obtainable probing depth of the left mandibular

first molar and second molar was 6 mm and 4 mm, respectively. The other maximum

obtainable probing depths were all 2 or 3 mm. However, Touch Test Sensory

Evaluators showed hypoesthesia of the left lower lip with the complaint of numbness

of the region (Vincent's symptom), which suggested the possibility of the presence of

mandibular osteomyelitis.

Pantomography and dental X-ray indicated furcation involvement of the left

mandibular first molar. The furcation involvement was classified into the Class II by

the classification by Hamp and Nyman and Lindhe's classification. In addition,

interestingly, marked and independent swelling of the buccal alveolar bone at the left

mandibular first molar was observed. On the day following the patient's first visit to

the oral and maxillofacial surgery department, the gram-positive cocchi turned out to

be S. constellatus, which is known to be part of the normal flora in the oral cavity.

This result suggested that the infectious focus was in the patient's oral cavity and

prompted us to conduct a closer examination of the oral lesion.

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was not an option for this patient because she

had undergone a cochlear implantation, but an enhanced computerized tomography

(CT) scan indicated the mixture of acute and chronic osteomyelitis in the left

mandible.

First suspicion that the acute symptoms of chronic osteomyelitis in her left mandible

could have led to the systemic infection. The furcation involvement and/or dental

caries in the left mandibular first molar was/were considered the primary focus of her

current acute symptoms. Therefore, first the metal crown was removed on the left

mandibular first molar. Because of the effect of the initial empirical administration of

an antibiotic, no suppuration was observed, but a clear carious lesion expanding

from the branch of the roots to the distal root was observed. Specimens from the soft

dentin of the carious lesion was sampled for a culture-test, which revealed

methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and Enterococcus faecalis

(Group D streptococci). This result implied that there had been an aggressive battle

between the antibiotics administered to the patient and invasive bacteria. Medical

staff removed as much of the infected soft dentin of the left mandibular first molar as

possible, and the molar was eventually extracted under the administration of i.v.

vancomycin (1 g every 12 h) and p.o. clyndamycin (300 mg every 8 h) after the

patient’s general condition had recovered.
Response:
Diagnosis:

Sepsis due to odontogenic infection

* Probability: High
* Emergency: Immediate medical attention required
* Rationale: Correctly diagnosed by the engine

Suitable Treatments:
* Broad spectrum antibiotic (change to specfic antibiotic after colture analisis), fluid (crystalloids) replacement (to be established according to fluid tolerance and fluid responsiveness), norepinephrine to mantain mean arterial pressure above 65 mmHg (adding vasopressin in case of refractory shock),  ventilation support (mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 6 ml/kg is preferred)

Query:
12 yo, M patient, territorial medicine setting, mild urgency

Patient went to visit with his mother. The reason of the visit was weakness, coughing, mild fever, productive cough, vomit. The symptoms started with fever (BT 37.5°C), weakness, loss of concentration, dry cough. The cough was very intense and frequent (4-5 cough hit simultaneously). After few days the cough became productive and appeared vomit. The vomit characteristics were not associated to a gastric pathology or to meal, it was poor, sometimes he vomited only his saliva. The symptoms get worse at evening. There not sign of viral infection like wheezing or rhinorrhoea. The cough, in the first days dry, was associated to catarrh or yellow or white color. At auscultation, lung were free. Mild throat pain and swelling. Patient did not complete vaccine cicle. Antigen exam was positive for B. pertussis.
Response:
Diagnosis:

pertussis 

* Probability: High
* Emergency: Immediate medical attention required
* Rationale: The patient presents with characteristic symptoms of pertussis, including a prolonged dry cough, fever, weakness, and vomiting. The positive antigen test for B. pertussis confirms the diagnosis.
Suitable Treatments:
* (azitromicin 10-12 mg/kg/day for 5 days), support therapy

Query:
A 2 yo M patient child, territorial and ED setting. Relevant clinical history of early preterm birth and bronchopneumonia. 

He presented to territorial doctor a 7 day history of cough and fever. The child was immediately transferred to the Children’s Assessment Unit at the local university hospital. On examination the child had a RR of 60 breaths per minute and a HR of 180 bpm; was febrile and had a cough and wheeze. A chest radiograph showed nothing abnormal. The child was given salbutamol (through nebulisation) which improved oxygen saturation from 93% to 99% and was discharged with a diagnosis of viral wheeze. Blood sample for routine investigations along with a pernasal swab was taken during this consultation.

First diagnosis: viral wheeze

Therapy: anti-inflammatory drugs

The following day the child was seen by his regular family doctor and was found to be afebrile, well in himself and had a mild expiratory wheeze. He was given steroids (prednisolone) for 3 d and a delayed prescription for amoxicillin. As the cough and wheeze still persisted the child’s parents ensured this course of antibiotics was completed. However the child remained unwell with cough and minimal wheeze even after this.

A pernasal swab was collected in the Children’s Assessment Unit of the local University Hospital which was received in the microbiology laboratory on the same day. The sample was processed as per the standard operating procedure (SOP) of the laboratory.

Oxidase test revealed a positive reaction (B.parapertussis gives a negative oxidase reaction). A slide agglutination test with B. pertussis polyvalent antiserum gave a positive result. Based on these tests performed in the laboratory, a presumptive diagnosis of B. pertussis was made. The isolate was subsequently referred to the Respiratory and Systemic Infection Laboratory for confirmation.

 

Further tests were performed on the isolate at the HPA’s Pertussis reference laboratory and was confirmed to be Bordetella pertussis serotype 1 and serotype 3.

Confirmation from the microbiology laboratory, together with the clinical diagnosis led to the conclusion that the vaccination had failed or persistence of vaccine-induced protection was weak. The child was prescribed Azithromycin, 125 mg every 6 h for 7 d. The child was seen again by the family doctor two weeks later and was still coughing and had a wheeze. On this occasion Clarithromycin, 62.5 mg twice a day for 7 d was prescribed. Following this the child completely recovered and was given a booster vaccination.
Response:
Diagnosis:

Bordetella Pertussis Infection

* Probability: High
* Emergency: High
* Rationale: The positive slide agglutination test, the oxidase test, and further confirmation at the Pertussis reference laboratory make this a definitive diagnosis. The clinical history and symptoms (persistent cough, preterm birth history, and bronchopneumonia) align with pertussis.

Suitable Treatments:
* antibiotic (Azithromycin and clarithromycin)

Query:
7 yo M patient, ED setting.
He was admitted to the ED having had fever for 6 days, headache, vomiting, maculopapular rash, severe abdominal pain, conjunctival hyperemia, photophobia, raspberry tongue, hyperemia with lip desquamation, right cervical lymphadenomegaly, and edema. In addition, he experienced mild tachypnea without respiratory symptoms when breathing normal room air.
On admission, the patient underwent a fluorescence immunoassay for SARS-CoV-2 to test for the presence of reagent immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies, with titers >30.0 AU/mL (normal, <1.4 AU/mL) and antibodies nonreactive to immunoglobulin M (IgM), with a titer of 0.1 AU (normal, <1.1 AU). The mother reported that the child had flu-like symptoms 1 month before admission. Laboratory tests indicated inflammatory responses (Table 1). His C-reactive protein measured 96 mg/dL, blood count showed lymphopenia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia; hypoalbuminemia (2.3 g/dL); hypertriglyceridemia (262 mg/dL); and increased levels of transaminases, ferritin (1812 ng/mL), d-dimer (8500 ng/mL), and troponin (0.26 ng/mL). The patients blood type was O positive. Serology tests for dengue IgG and IgM and anti-HIV were nonreactive. Serology tests for toxoplasmosis, cytomegalovirus, Epstein–Barr virus, herpes simplex 1 and 2, and rubella were all negative. Blood culture for aerobic and anaerobic microbes using selective media showed no bacterial growth. Urine culture also revealed no bacterial growth.
